cs351.utility

Class ParallelJobSystem

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs351.utility.ParallelJobSystem

  • public final class ParallelJobSystem
extends java.lang.Object
    A ParallelJobSystem provides an easy way to manage up to 256 threads. The best way to use it is to have only one job system for an entire program but many different separate job lists (see the JobList class). Each separate job list can interact with the same job system so that its jobs can be submitted to the job system's worker threads.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      ParallelJobSystem(int numWorkerThreads)
      Creates a new job system with the specified number of worker threads.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ParallelJobSystem

        public ParallelJobSystem(int numWorkerThreads)
        Creates a new job system with the specified number of worker threads. This number is used when the init() function is called in order to create and start that number of workers. Note that the current max number of worker threads is 256.
        Parameters:
        numWorkerThreads - number of worker threads on the range of [1, 256]

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init()
          throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Initializes the job system for use. Once this is called, all worker threads are created and started. This function is meant to be called exactly once per job system object.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if the job system is used after destruction or initialized twice

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Destroys the job system. After this the object should not be used again.

      • submit

        public java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger submit(java.util.Collection<Job> jobs,
                                                        int priority,
                                                        boolean clearGivenJobList)
                                                 throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Submits a job list to the job system. The job system makes no guarantee that the worker threads will see the list immediately (if ever in the event that all worker threads are stuck with infinite-loop jobs for some reason). Instead, when worker threads are signalling that more work is needed, the job system will at that point try to push previously-submitted jobs to the front buffer.
        Parameters:
        jobs - list of jobs to execute
        priority - their priority (lower numbers being higher priority)
        clearGivenJobList - if true, the given job list is wiped
        Returns:
        an atomic integer representing a counter - when the counter is 0, the job list has been completed by the worker threads
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if used after destruction or before init

      • signalWork

        public void signalWork(int threadID)
                throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        Allows the worker threads to let the job system know that previous job lists were completed. At this point the job system will try to push previously-submitted jobs to the front buffer (if no jobs are left in the queue) and give more work to the worker threads. Note that if one worker thread asks for more work and the job system makes the effort to accommodate the request, *all* worker threads will receive more work in the hopes that the job system won't be asked for more work immediately after a request.
        Parameters:
        threadID - id of the thread that needs more work
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - thrown if an unknown worker signals for more work which should never happen

      • notifyOfThreadTermination

        public void notifyOfThreadTermination(int threadID)
                               throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        This is used by worker threads to let the job system know that they have stopped execution. Once all threads have finished, the job system sets a flag letting itself know that it is done and then prints a message to the console.
        Parameters:
        threadID - id of the thread - used to make sure the thread is legit
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - thrown if the thread id is invalid for this job system

      • getNumActiveThreads

        public int getNumActiveThreads()
        Gets the number of worker threads.
        Returns:
        number of worker threads

      • isInitialized

        public boolean isInitialized()
        Checks to see whether the job system is available for work or not - using it when this returns false will likely throw an exception.
        Returns:
        true if initialized and false if not
